flashcards.title: Purtscher Retinopathy
flashcards.description: This 21 year old male noted a significant unilateral decrease in vision two days after an all-terrain vehicle (ATV) roll-over accident in which he suffered head trauma and a fractured rib. Radiating superficial retinal ischemia is seen here with scattered blot hemorrhages and venous dilation in the right eye. His left eye was unaffected. True Purtscher's Retinopathy was originally described in cases of known head-trauma, but this clinical picture can also be seen in a variety of disease mechanisms including chest compression, long-bone fracture, acute pancreatitis, and connective tissue disorders amongst others.
flashcards.photographer: Brice Critser, CRA and Susan Wright, CRA

flashcards.title: Coats Disease
flashcards.description: Posted: 06/03/2024 An 8-year-old boy was evaluated for unilateral retinal vascular abnormalities. On exam, he had clusters of retinal telangiectasias (white arrows) in the far periphery with extrafoveal exudation (orange arrows). This is consistent with a diagnosis of Coats disease, stage 2A. "

flashcards.title: Acute Retinal Necrosis
flashcards.description: Posted: 06/03/2024 A 65-year-old man presented with new onset cobwebs, floaters, and decreased vision in the right eye. He had underlying diabetes mellitus with known non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy but was otherwise immunocompetent. On dilated fundus examination there was moderate vitritis with sheet like patches of homogeneous peripheral whitening anterior to the equator, consistent with acute retinal necrosis (ARN). There is no visible vitreous traction or retinal tear or detachment. There is also vascular sheathing predominantly of the arterioles, which favors an underlying etiology of varicella zoster virus as the cause of ARN.

flashcards.title: Kearns-Sayre syndrome
flashcards.description: Posted: 07/01/2024 25 year-old female presented with bilateral ptosis since age 18, severe ophthalmoplegia, and salt-and-pepper retinopathy. She also had short stature at 5'1.8", fatigue, and weakness of her face, neck, and proximal extremities. She had undergone previous surgery for bilateral upper eyelid ptosis. She had poor levator function of both eyes. ERG showed global photoreceptor dysfunction

images.alt: Severe limitation in all ductions bilaterally.
Right eye with normal optic nerve and salt-and-pepper retinopathy.
Left eye with normal optic nerve and salt-and-pepper retinopathy.

flashcards.title: Bilateral Retinoschisis-Associated Retinal Detachments in Pars Planitis
flashcards.description: Posted: 09/18/2024 A 15-year-old female with pars planitis, controlled for 2 years on adalimumab and methotrexate, presented for a new-onset superonasal visual field defect in the left eye. Fundus photography (A, B) showed inferior retinoschisis (yellow arrows) with associated retinal detachments (white arrows) in both eyes. B-scan of the right eye showed a double-layer sign (C). OCT in the left eye confirmed subretinal fluid into the macula. Due to a demarcation line, the right eye was cautiously observed, and the left eye underwent emergent retinal detachment repair.
flashcards.contributor: Emma M. Hartness, BS; Scott A. Larson, MD; Timothy M. Boyce, MD
flashcards.photographer: Alexandra Copple, Ashley Ollinger, Sarah Skiles, CRA

images.alt: Right and left optic discs appear structurally congested and tilted with situs inversus of the retinal vessels.
B-scan ultrasound is a useful adjunct to confirm splitting of the retinal layers in the periphery.

flashcards.title: Focal Scleral Nodule
flashcards.description: Posted: 06/30/2025 Focal scleral nodules (previously called solitary idiopathic choroiditis or unifocal helioid choroiditis) are rare, amelanotic, intrascleral lesions localized to the posterior segment of the eye. They are often elevated and yellow or white in color. These lesions are typically asymptomatic and are incidentally found on dilated fundus exam. It is uncertain whether the lesions are congenital or the result of an old inflammatory process. In the case shown here, there was overlying retinal pigment epithelium disruption without subretinal fluid. If asymptomatic, these lesions are observed without intervention
flashcards.contributor: Lauren A. Tomlinson MD; Nicole A. Somani MD; Elaine M. Binkley MD

images.alt: Figure 1: Fundus photography of the right eye showing a yellow-orange lesion inferior to the inferior arcade. Atrophy can be seen at the apex of the lesion

Figure 2: OCT macula of the right eye showing elevation of the lesion as well as mild subretinal high-reflective material over the apex. There was no subretinal fluid. The lesion appears to originate from the sclera, compressing the choroid above it.

Figure 3: Longitudinal B-scan ocular ultrasound of the right eye at the 7 o�clock position demonstrating a small, localized calcified lesion inferotemporal to the nerve, corresponding to the focal scleral nodule.

flashcards.title: Pentosan Polysulfate Maculopathy
flashcards.description: A 62-year-old woman taking pentosan polysulfate (PPS) for interstitial cystitis (200 mg twice daily for 20 years; cumulative dose >2,500 g) underwent a baseline dilated exam. She reported several years of nyctalopia. Examination showed pigmentary retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) stippling with nummular macular atrophy extending toward the temporal optic disc margins (Figure 1). Fundus autofluorescence (FAF) demonstrated a speckled pattern of macular hyper- and hypoautofluorescence with peripapillary involvement (Figure 2). Optical coherence tomography (OCT) revealed diffuse RPE excrescences and outer retinal atrophy (Figure 3). Findings were consistent with pentosan polysulfate (PPS)–associated maculopathy
flashcards.contributor: Joanna I.M. Silverman, MD, Brian P. Young, Elliott H. Sohn, MD, FASRS, FARVO

images.alt: Figure 1. Fundus photography of right and left eyes demonstrating pigmentary retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) stippling and nummular atrophy of the maculae extending to the temporal nerves.
Figure 2. Fundus autofluorescence demonstrating macular speckled hyper- and hypoautofluorescence centered around the fovea and optic nerves.
Figure 3. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) demonstrating diffuse RPE excrescences and outer retinal atrophy.

flashcards.title: Retinal Arterial Venous Malformation
flashcards.description: A 64-year-old woman was found on routine examination to have severe tortuosity of the superior arcade vessels in the right eye consistent with an arterial venous malformation (AVM). The other eye had moderately dilated and tortuous retinal vasculature. Retinal AVMs can be seen in isolation as an acquired anomaly or as an ophthalmic finding in Wyburn-Mason Syndrome, a rare congenital disorder characterized by AVMs in the retina and brain. Vision loss in AVMs may occur due to complications such as vascular occlusion. In this patient, MRI/MRA brain was negative for brain AVMs, and regular surveillance was advised. Figure 1: right eye fundus photo showing a large arterial venous malformation with severe tortuosity at the superior arcade and moderate tortuosity at the inferior arcade OD
flashcards.contributor: Lauren A. Tomlinson, MD; Jonathan F. Russell, MD, PhD; and Ryan J. Diel MD

images.alt: right eye fundus photo showing a large arterial venous malformation with severe tortuosity at the superior arcade and moderate tortuosity at the inferior arcade OD
left eye fundus photo showing moderately dilated and tortuous retinal vasculature

flashcards.title: Myelinated nerve fiber layer
flashcards.description: Updated: August 18, 2025; Original: September 9, 2013 Myelination of the optic nerve fibers normally begins at the lateral geniculate body and ceases at the lamina cribosa. However, in some individuals areas of the retinal nerve fiber layer can also become myelinated. Classically, this finding is unilateral and peripapillary in location, appearing as a white, flame-shaped area with feathered borders as seen in the top photo. However, it can also present bilaterally in 7% of these patients as illustrated in the middle photo.(1) The bottom photo shows a less common presentation affecting a more extensive distribution of the peripheral nerve fibers. Note how the nerve fibers temporal to the macula respect the horizontal raphe, a concept not easily visualized under normal conditions
flashcards.photographer: Brice Critser, CRA (top image); Alexandra Copple, CRA (middle images); and Stefani Karakas, CRA (bottom image)

images.alt: Myelinated nerve fiber layer, right eye
